current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text:
To provide for the issuance of a forever stamp to honor the sacrifices of the brave men and women
			 of the Armed Forces who are still prisoner, missing, or unaccounted for,
			 and for other purposes.

sponsor.#tail: introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the

committee-name.#text: Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

the United States
			 Government has an obligation to—

achieve the fullest possible accounting
			 for the
			 people of the United States who have gone missing while serving the
			 country; and

in 1982, the
			 National League of Families POW/MIA flag (referred to in this Act as the

, enacted on August 10,
			 1990,	designated the POW/MIA flag as

quote.#text:
the symbol of
			 our Nation’s concern and commitment to resolving as fully as possible the
			 fates
			 of Americans still prisoner, missing and unaccounted for in Southeast

text.#text:
the POW/MIA flag
			 should maintain continued visibility as a constant reminder of the plight
			 of
			  the people of the United States who are prisoners of war or missing in
			 action.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall issue
			 a
			 forever stamp that—

text.#text:
In order to continue to honor the sacrifices of the brave
			 men and women of the Armed Forces who have been prisoners of war, missing
			 in action, or
			 unaccounted for, the
is suitable for that purpose; and

For
			 purposes of this Act, the term

meets the postage required for first-class mail up to 1
			 ounce in
			 weight; and

retains full validity for the postage described in paragraph (1) even if the rate
			 of
			 that postage is later increased.

The stamp described in subsection (a) shall be issued
			 beginning as soon as practicable after the date of enactment of this
			 Act
			 and shall not thereafter be discontinued.
